1. Effectiveness of policy implementation. 2. BAT/BEP demonstration; Data information management system established. 3. National replication and incentive scheme 4. Training and promotional activities. 5. Recruitment of 1 international and 1 national consultant for the project terminal evaluation.

1. At the project closure, total 8 standards related to emission control were promulgated, with 2 additional standards under development. Based on the standards, certificates were issued for more than 400 companies. The standards will play important roles in the sustainable development of secondary metallurgy industry in China and beyond. 2. The project provided support for procurement of equipment for 4 selected technologies that were subsequently installed and commissioned at the two demonstration companies. This enabled to achieve the dioxin content in the emission below 0.1ng TEQ/m3 and treatment of residues with sound manner. According to the data provided by an independent verifier, the two demonstration companies achieved the total reduction of dioxin emissions of 46.20 g TEQ (43.48 g TEQ from flue gas emissions and 2.72 g TEQ from residues emissions) and exceeded thus the pre-set objective of 11.88g TEQ. 3. In total, 18 incentive programme companies (8 Smelting companies and 10 dismantling companies). For the smelting companies, the flue gas dioxin emission concentrations of the 8 enterprises were all lower than 0.1 ng TEQ/m3. The reduction of dioxin is 386.52 g TEQ in flue gas and 21.17g TEQ in residues gives the total reduction 407.69 g TEQ. 4. More than 120 related articles were posted on internet platforms for public awareness on the dioxin reduction efforts. The browsing is recorded as 84,000 times. Several other public awareness materials were developed including movies, cartoons, interviews, and songs. More than 20 movies had been compiled with more than 1250,000 times of broadcasting. 5. The terminal evaluation has been completed, the project was rated as highly satisfactory. TE package has been uploaded to ERC.

1. This area of work is on-track. Cumulative progress to date is approximately 100%, as 2 policy research/ evaluations on pollution prevention technologies and associated economic policies of the reclaimed copper smelting have so far been completed. In the next reporting period, the corresponding policy assessment reports will be submitted to the Ministry of Environmental Protection, the Ministry of Finance, and the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology as reference materials for policy formulation work. 2.In this reporting period, the project manager and relevant management personnel visited Singapore and Japan recycling plants in 2019 to exchange views in reducing UPOPs emissions and particular cases of advanced UPOPs emission reduction technologies in secondary non-ferrous metal sectors. 3.The Manual for Environmental Management of Hazardous Waste in the Recycled Copper Smelting Industry in Jiangxi Province is being prepared. This manual will guide enterprises in both standardizing the disposal of hazardous waste generated from secondary copper production and provide a reference for local environmental departments managing and inspecting secondary copper enterprises. At this reporting period, This area of work is completed. 4.This area of work is on-track. Cumulative progress to date is approximately 80%. 1. This area of work is on-track. This activity has been completed. Two policy research/evaluations on pollution prevention technologies and associated economic policies of secondary copper industry and four technical standards have been completed. 2. For this component of work, the activities are 80% completed. The two demonstration enterprises have completed the BAT/BEP measures to reduce dioxin emissions. 3. In this reporting period, the project manager from FECO attended the 39th International Symposium on Halogenated Persistent Organic Pollutants (DIOXIN2019) in August 25-30 2019, to share the research results and experience of secondary copper project with the international participants; FECO organized trips to Singapore and Japan in October 20-26, 2019, to carry out POPs pollution prevention and management policies and technical exchange activities in secondary non-ferrous metal industry. 4. This area of work is completed. The hazardous waste management manual of Jiangxi secondary copper smelting industry was prepared and distributed to Jiangxi secondary non-ferrous metal enterprises and local environmental protection departments. The environmental management manual plays an important role in hazardous waste management and dioxin pollution prevention and control in Jiangxi Province. 5. This area of work is 100% completed. Current data and the latest project progress have been regularly updated on China’s official POPs website to disseminate information about the management of secondary copper smelting enterprises. Up to now, through the information platform, 586 enterprises in 24 provinces have been issued emission permits, including 192 secondary copper, 266 secondary aluminum, 80 secondary lead and 48 secondary zinc enterprises, covering most of Chinas nonferrous metal industrial enterprises. The information platform includes: basic information of enterprises, production process, pollutant emission data, pollutant emission permit, etc. 6. This area of work is on-track. Cumulative progress to date is approximately 80%. Through the promotion of projects, FECO has also established regular coordination mechanisms among different departments of Stockholm Convention, Rotterdam Convention, Mercury Convention and SAICM. 7. At this reporting period, things are now estimated at 100% completion. The project plans to carry out a mid-term evaluation of the park management demonstration based on PPP mode in Tongling Park in November 2020, and carry out terminal evaluation before June 2021. 8. At this reporting period, things are now estimated at 80% completion. In May 2020, the project started the bidding process and planned to award 14 enterprises that meet the requirements. As of 2020 period, 13 enterprises have submitted letters of interest. 9. By the end of June 2020, 98 training sessions has been conducted. 1,888 governmental officials, 1,825 technical workers, 13,485 enterprise managers and 2,330 general public participated in the trainings, which up to 90% progress to date based on the target of 300 officials (100% completed), 2,000 technical workers (91% completed) and 2330 general public (0.23%).
